name: NEH - AstroBiotics
description: Deck I took to summer tournament Aug 30th in Santa Monica, CA. Inazuma is the best thing ever. I will likely replace the Ash with a 2nd copy.

name: toolpad-v2.75
description: The breaker/tutor suite for this deck has remained unchanged for a while, the PPVP + event economy works pretty well w/ pro co to smooth out the draw/econ situation. Imp meant I couldn't run legwork, but man was it useful for killing biotic/sansan.

name: How I Met Your Overmind Challenge v2.0
description:
Rebuild of my previous Exile Overmind deck, after listening and pondering on Damon Stone's Team Covenant interview. The idea behind the deck is to spend as little credits as possible on breaking ICE.

The constant Scavenging/Test Running from the Heap should keep the card draw up, and synergises with the LLDS Processor to reduce credit costs. e3 synergises with all the breakers if necessary, and provides an alternative to using power counters on Bioroids. Helpful AIs are there to provide a further boost to a freshly-installed Overmind for those big runs.

The biggest spend in the deck is the Toolbox, which once installed will provide some income (recurring credits plus the Link to turn on Underworld Contacts), more MU for Overmind counters and Link to (possibly) let trace routines fire (Helpful AI helps here too).

name: My Polish Nationals deck (2nd in Swiss, 7th in Top 8)
description:
My version of the popular deck based on Domestic Sleepers. As with the runner deck I did not playtest this much and most decisions were based more on intuition than experience. Here I felt that the deck will be extremely weak against Parasite decks. I could not decide if I should go with Lotus Fields or with Targeted Marketings and now I think that I should play them both :) Targeted Marketing did a great job (popular targets: Special Order, Account Siphon, Parasite, whatever someone had on his Personal Workshop ;P) but two copies was too little to protect myself against parasites.

The money is tight, you really want to use JAckson Howard to re-use the 9 money operations. This makes Noise a hard match up - you end up using Jackson to reshuffle agendas and you don't have enough money.

The deck went 5-1 in Swiss (wins against two Shapers and two anarchs, one win and one lose against Andromeda) but it lost me both game sin the Top 8 (first I got eaten by Parasites, in the second one it was a tight game which I might have one if I got some agendas earlier).

name: My Polish Nationals deck (2nd in Swiss, 7th after top 8)
description:
I played about three games with this deck before the Nationals so it was in no way tested against the current meta. My feeling was that a successful Gabe must be richer than he needed to be a couple months back so I took out some tricks (Emergency Shutdowns, one Inside Job) and replaced them with Armitages and Stimhack.

In the Swiss the deck went 4-2 having no problems against two HB Big Ice decks and one HB FA and managed a lucky win against Hobb's Jinteki RP (I won two psi games for Future Perfect, if I would lose one of them I would most likely lose the game).

I lost against a Weyland heavy Scorched Earth deck (no Plascretes ;)) and against NBN NEH. In the Top 8 I played both games with the Corporation.

Today I would do one change: Net Celebrity would become a Mimic - as I did not play much after The Spaces Between I did not know what to expect from the currents so I decided to add one as a safety net and it turned out to be completely unnecessary. On the other hand breaking all the sentries with Faerie's was at some times difficult (Same Old Special Order -> Faerie for the win! ;))

name: Weyland - The root of evil
description: a classic weyland (SEA source and Scorched) with the root to pay some ICE or agenda

name: Feed the Nasir
Tennin Secret Experiments
Cached Memories v0.2
(N)ow (A)dd (S)nitch (I)nto (R)esearch
description:
I was disappointed with the Blackstone-Kits performance in mid/late game so here's the snitched Toolbox-Nasir.

  1. the Snitch. Starting hand with Snitch, take it, draw a card, build the Snitch and start looking for ICE that don't do damage. Install stuff down to zero creds, run on the 1st click and do what Nasir is here for - cashing from rezzing. A big barrier with nothing than "end the run"-subs gives you the money for the next install-round.

  2. Breaker-Suite. Two of the breakers should be placed on the omni-drives; depending on the corp-ID and the gamestate (start snitching early) you should upgrade the Gordian or the Snowball with two Personal Touch - safes a lot of money in the endgame. If you draw them early, build one on the Dagger to safe stealth-creds.

  3. "No snitch and I'm afraid to run into a sentry". Dagger with two stealth-creds hacks every(!) rezzed sentry while still making you money. Same goes for the rest of the breakers, you just don't need the creds stealthed. Because it's so awesome, again: you just need two of those for facechecking every ICE while having zero creds.

  4. Mid&End-Game Eco is simply done with recurring creds. Without the Ghost Runner, you should have 6-12 of them which is more than enough for the R&D-Lock, especially when your breakers keep their strength and the Corp didn't pay attention. I had a Magnum Opus in there but kicked it for the SMCs because I never used it and switched to Armitage - much better.

  5. Sahasrara, Leprechaun and the Netshield are usually the programs you adapt to your meta. Dropped them once for three Makers Eye and won on 1st turn (Corp didn't ice the RND and I drew two of them after a mulligan - ouch) but if you play them, you have a lot less worries about a lot of things: MU, ECO and damage.

  6. I'm still divided about the Xanadu. True, installed at the 1st turn, it really brings the corp into an awfull situation but for that I'd need to splash at least two of them, which I can't. Having just one and drawing it in mid/end-game is basically a dead card and I'm thinking "mayby an E3 for those pesky bioroids".

Suggestions?

name: Dec@Day.02 - Trojan Whale
description:
Dec@Day - Every identity, one day and deck at a time. It's like NaNoWriMo for Netrunner! More info in my profile.

Noise: Hacker Extraordinaire is my favorite ID of the Core Set, giving the Runner pressure on Archives just for playing what we draw. Getting a Wyldside in play is critical for drawing the Caches, Cyberfeeders, and Sahasraras that keep the deck going. Aesop's Pawnshop lets us turn off Wyldside and pitch our spent Imps and Daily Casts for even more econ.

The two main breakers, Darwin and Knight, get us in for the multi-access that Medium and Nerve Agent provide, and whenever the Corp spends their turn to purge virus counters, it's an excellent opportunity to see what we've milled in Archives. Saying hi to all the dead ICE that Parasite sent there is optional.

Suggestions, critiques or comments? Feel free--the entire reason I'm doing this is to build my deckbuilding skills--and stop by tomorrow for Jinteki: Personal Evolution's turn.

Previous Dec@Day Decks:

  • 01 HB: EtF - Fix It in Beta

name: Lorenz attractor 1.0
Glacier Factory
Notorious C.H.A.O.S.V4
description:
Notoriety deck with Doppleganger, All-Nighter and cheap Crim central breakers, with Quest Completed to avoid having to break into those huge external servers.

Indexing helps keep the Corp focused on keeping you out of R&D, which makes it easy for Escher to put 3 Pop-Up Windows in front of it...

name: Too Many Astros
description: Test for our local Mad Professor challenge. Derived from Too Many Sexbots by Running With Scissors

name: Maker Faire
description:
Welcome to Maker Faire! Learn tips of the trade for producing whatever like in your own personal workshop. Expand your network of contacts with both professional and underworld makers who can help you source those hard to find bits and earn a bit on the side.

Personal Workshop is the key to this deck. A lot of the hardware and programs are really expensive. It is critical to get them loaded onto a workshop as soon as possible. When running you'll use anything on the workshop as a credit dump before gaining credits for a rez'd ice.

Nasir needs plenty of card draw, which is why Professional Contacts fits so well. Coupled with Diesel you will find that you will work through your deck fairly quickly.

When looking at opening hands the order of preference is Workshop, then ProCon. If you don't have either of these, mulligan.

Xanadu can be more than just a nuisance to the corp and money for you, it can be a lifesaver. When encountering a Popup Window or Pup you would normally be too poor to get by them on credits alone. Xanadu fixes that right up.

As far as economy goes, I get a lot of my credits from the corp. ProCon supplements that as I draw, and Underworld Contacts will supply clickless credits at the start of each turn. There are a number of ways to get the second link needed to trigger these off. The Toolbox will definitely get you there, and the Helpful AI also harmonizes well with the fixed strength breakers.

Speaking of fixed strength breakers, they seem an easy pairing with Nasir. They are extremely cheap to operate, and the high install cost is mitigated by the workshop. Getting into a long game can mean that the corp no longer has ice to rez, limiting Nasir's income. The fixed strength breakers are a boon here. I've found Femme to be effective simply as a threat as it sits on the workshop, letting the corp know that any tricks they may want to employ can be bypassed. Sharpshooter is Archer antidote, and Deus X is present to avoid any Jinteki hi-jinks. SMC is here only in the case that I can't get the workshop loaded up quickly enough.

In play, I've found that I regularly go through the entire deck. I've included Levy and Same Old Thing particularly to combat Jinteki.

Overall, I don't think this deck is reliable enough to see tournament play, but it is a lot of fun for casual play. Nasir forces the corp to make unique decisions when rezzing ice, and it is a lot of fun to see them squirm.

name: Meh NEH
description:
Move along, nothing interesting to see here....

NEH is strong. Not broken strong, but strong. It's also consistent. There are no big surprises in this deck. It is focused on one thing: fast advance.

Mental Health Clinic is here as I feel it is more effective than PAD Campaign or especially Marked Accounts. It does suffer a lower trash cost, but runners are rarely eager to pay 3 credits to reduce their own hand size.

name: Nasir the great
description: My only problem with this deck is thinking of Nasir's power as a problem to be mitigated rather than a strength to be exploited.

name: Starter Noise
description: A core-only Noise, for those who want to learn how to run.

name: Central Exposure
description: First time publishing a deck. I hope to have some advise! They are all welcomed!

name: Core HB
description: An HB SuperServer deck, with just one copy of the core set.
